L2_gloss: The first letter of the Lingala alphabet, written in the Latin script.
The personal pronoun, 3rd person plural form; they.
verbal prefix for second person plural
The personal pronoun, 1st person plural form; we.

river
1981,  Eyamba G. Bokamba,  Ekolongonelo Ya Lingala: An Introductory Textbook and Grammar:Mobembo o Ebale Zaire.A trip on the Zaire River.
1989,  John A. Holm,  Pidgins and Creoles: Volume 2, Reference Survey:ebale mpó á-sokola nzóto mpé á-melathe-river for he-wash-SUBJUNC body and he-drink-SUBJUNC

to go, to leave
kɛndɛ́ malámu (goodbye, said to someone leaving; lit. go well)
palm of the hand, testicle, (by extension) penis
sanza; mbira; likembe, sound produced in the throat
to love, to desire; to want
a ten, a group of ten
Matadi (a city in the Democratic Republic of the Congo)
Mbandaka (a city in the Democratic Republic of the Congo)
palm (tree); (in particular) the oil palm, Elaeis guineensis
Eru or African jointfir: a species of plant (Gnetum
skin, Synonym: lomposo, paper, letter (written message),
paste, more particularly palm butter or peanut butter
a lot of, many, Synonym: ebelé, Antonym: mokɛ́
with, and, in, at, of (form of ya before personal pronouns)
to believe, to have faith in
The first person singular pronoun; I.

news, information
nsango malámu / nsango elámu (good news, gospel)
nsango níni? (How are things?, lit. What news?)
to proclaim, to declare, to announce
to rejoice, be happy, have fun
to thin, to become thinner, to slim
to make thin, to annoy, to disturb, to vex, to irritate
